verses.verse: A good name<WH8034> is better<WH2896> than precious<WH2896> ointment<WH8081>; and the day<WH3117> of death<WH4194> than the day<WH3117> of one's birth<WH3205>.

¶ It is better<WH2896> to go<WH3212> to the house<WH1004> of mourning<WH60>, than to go<WH3212> to the house<WH1004> of feasting<WH4960>: for<WH834> that is the end<WH5490> of all men<WH120>; and the living<WH2416> will lay<WH5414> it to his heart<WH3820>.
Sorrow<WH3708> is better<WH2896> than laughter<WH7814>: for by the sadness<WH7455> of the countenance<WH6440> the heart<WH3820> is made better<WH3190>.
The heart<WH3820> of the wise<WH2450> is in the house<WH1004> of mourning<WH60>; but the heart<WH3820> of fools<WH3684> is in the house<WH1004> of mirth<WH8057>.
It is better<WH2896> to hear<WH8085> the rebuke<WH1606> of the wise<WH2450>, than for a man<WH376> to hear<WH8085> the song<WH7892> of fools<WH3684>.
For as the crackling<WH6963> of thorns<WH5518> under a pot<WH5518>, so is the laughter<WH7814> of the fool<WH3684>: this also is vanity<WH1892>.
¶ Surely oppression<WH6233> maketh a wise man<WH2450> mad<WH1984>; and a gift<WH4979> destroyeth<WH6> the heart<WH3820>.
Better<WH2896> is the end<WH319> of a thing<WH1697> than the beginning<WH7225> thereof: and the patient<WH750> in spirit<WH7307> is better<WH2896> than the proud<WH1362> in spirit<WH7307>.
Be not hasty<WH926> in thy spirit<WH7307> to be angry<WH3707>: for anger<WH3708> resteth<WH5117> in the bosom<WH2436> of fools<WH3684>.
Say<WH559> not thou, What is the cause that the former<WH7223> days<WH3117> were better<WH2896> than these? for thou dost not inquire<WH7592> wisely<WH2451> concerning this.
¶ Wisdom<WH2451> is good<WH2896> with an inheritance<WH5159>: and by it there is profit<WH3148> to them that see<WH7200> the sun<WH8121>.

For wisdom<WH2451> is a defence<WH6738>, and money<WH3701> is a defence<WH6738>: but the excellency<WH3504> of knowledge<WH1847> is, that wisdom<WH2451> giveth life<WH2421> to them that have<WH1167> it.
Consider<WH7200> the work<WH4639> of God<WH430>: for who can<WH3201> make that straight<WH8626>, which he hath made crooked<WH5791>?

In the day<WH3117> of prosperity<WH2896> be joyful<WH2896>, but in the day<WH3117> of adversity<WH7451> consider<WH7200>: God<WH430> also hath set<WH6213> the one over against<WH5980> the other, to the end<WH1700> that man<WH120> should find<WH4672> nothing<WH3972> after<WH310> him.

All things have I seen<WH7200> in the days<WH3117> of my vanity<WH1892>: there is<WH3426> a just<WH6662> man that perisheth<WH6> in his righteousness<WH6664>, and there is a wicked<WH7563> man that prolongeth<WH748> his life in his wickedness<WH7451>.
Be not righteous<WH6662> over much<WH7235>; neither make thyself over<WH3148> wise<WH2449>: why shouldest thou destroy<WH8074> thyself?
Be not over much<WH7235> wicked<WH7561>, neither be thou foolish<WH5530>: why shouldest thou die<WH4191> before thy time<WH6256>?

It is good<WH2896> that thou shouldest take hold<WH270> of this; yea, also from this<WH2088> withdraw<WH3240> not thine hand<WH3027>: for he that feareth<WH3373> God<WH430> shall come forth<WH3318> of them all.
Wisdom<WH2451> strengtheneth<WH5810> the wise<WH2450> more than ten<WH6235> mighty<WH7989> men which are in the city<WH5892>.
For there is not a just<WH6662> man<WH120> upon earth<WH776>, that doeth<WH6213> good<WH2896>, and sinneth<WH2398> not.
Also take<WH5414> no heed<WH3820> unto all words<WH1697> that are spoken<WH1696>; lest thou hear<WH8085> thy servant<WH5650> curse<WH7043> thee:
For oftentimes<WH6471><WH7227> also thine own heart<WH3820> knoweth<WH3045> that thou thyself likewise hast cursed<WH7043> others<WH312>.
¶ All this<WH2090> have I proved<WH5254> by wisdom<WH2451>: I said<WH559>, I will be wise<WH2449>; but it was far<WH7350> from me.
That which is far off<WH7350>, and exceeding deep<WH6013>, who can find it out<WH4672>?

I applied<WH5437> mine heart<WH3820> to know<WH3045>, and to search<WH8446>, and to seek out<WH1245> wisdom<WH2451>, and the reason<WH2808> of things, and to know<WH3045> the wickedness<WH7562> of folly<WH3689>, even of foolishness<WH5531> and madness<WH1947>:

And I find<WH4672> more bitter<WH4751> than death<WH4194> the woman<WH802>, whose heart<WH3820> is snares<WH4685> and nets<WH2764>, and her hands<WH3027> as bands<WH612>: whoso pleaseth<WH2896><WH6440> God<WH430> shall escape<WH4422> from her; but the sinner<WH2398> shall be taken<WH3920> by her.
Behold<WH7200>, this have I found<WH4672>, saith<WH559> the preacher<WH6953>, counting one<WH259> by one<WH259>, to find out<WH4672> the account<WH2808>:
Which yet my soul<WH5315> seeketh<WH1245>, but I find<WH4672> not: one<WH259> man<WH120> among a thousand<WH505> have I found<WH4672>; but a woman<WH802> among all those have I not found<WH4672>.
Lo<WH7200>, this only<WH905> have I found<WH4672>, that God<WH430> hath made<WH6213> man<WH120> upright<WH3477>; but they have sought out<WH1245> many<WH7227> inventions<WH2810>.
